awd_titl_txt: Creating a Continuum of Integrated STEM Learning Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will inform the body of knowledge about the importance and conduct of pre-college and undergraduate research and educational experiences in recruiting and retaining underrepresented individuals into STEM studies, and preparing the next generation of STEM professionals. The connection of faculty to research and thereby the students to culturally and locally relevant research and STEM instruction is an important step in graduating students who are more likely to pursue advanced degrees. For those students entering the workforce directly from a tribal college it is equally important that they have a well-defined skill set in mathematics, science, and technology for entry into the STEM workforce. 

The goal of this project is to provide a continuum of integrated learning experiences. The project will conduct intensive outreach and recruiting efforts among local junior high students, high school students and Fort Belknap community members; initiate a Scholars Summer Seminar program that will provide pre-college students with a relevant and engaging STEM learning experience embedded in a deep cultural context; develop and deliver thematic first-year seminars for all incoming STEM majors that will replace traditional developmental skills classes and will embed the teaching and learning of core academic skills and competencies within a content-rich and culturally-based context; establish discipline-specific first-year learning communities for STEM majors; expand summer research opportunities for STEM students; offer intensive summer field courses that enhance students' research and classroom experiences though international study and joint short-course offerings with Carroll College; and provide opportunities for on-site enrollment in, and completion of, baccalaureate degree programs from Carroll College.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project succeeded in achieving its goal of providing a continuum of integrated learning experiences that would increase participation, learning, and achievement among STEM students at Aaniiih Nakoda College (ANC), a tribally controlled college located in northcentral Montana. The project achieved this goal by offering STEM students an integrated pathway of learning opportunities that began with pre-college enrichment activities and culminated in completion of the college's first bachelor's degree program, a B.S. in Aaniiih Nakoda Ecology. Along the way, students participated in pre-college summer academies, first-year seminars, undergaduate research experiences, short-term field courses, and B.S. level coursework. The project's overall impact is reflected in its success in acheiving key project performance targets related to participation, learning, and achievement among the college's STEM students. For example, over the life of the project, STEM program enrollment increased by eight percent, and the number of STEM graduates increased by 14 percent. 

 Two project activities, in particular, had a transformative impact on student success and institutional capacity building. The first of these activities was the summer field course in Namibia (Project Activity #6). Students participating in the course spent three weeks in Namibia, where they studied the country's human and natural history; explored similarities and differences in American Indian and Namibian cultures; learned about environmental and social issues of common concern; conducted rangeland assessments; toured research facilities and conservation areas; and met with government officials, research scientists, community conservancy leaders, and representatives of indigenous communities. Over the life of the project, 29 ANC students participated in the Namibia field course, and student outcome data for these students suggest that the experience had a transformative impact on their academic success. For example, 96 percent of participants returned to college in the fall semester immediately following the summer course; in comparison, the college's annual retention rate hovers around 55 percent. Similarly, 72 percent of participants have gone on to earn their A.S. degree, while another 24 percent are currently enrolled in A.S. degree-granting programs. By contrast, ANC's institutional graduate rate is 33 percent. Most remarkably, among participants earning an A.S. degree, 57 percent have gone on to complete a bachelor's degree, while another 24 percent are currently pursuing a baccalaureate degree. Qualitative data from post-participation focus groups and interviews reinforce the conclusion that participation in the Namibia field course had a transformative impact on students' academic and personal lives.  

The other transformative project activity resulted in the development and delivery of the college's first bachelor's degree program, a B.S. degree in Aaniiih Nakoda Ecology (Project Activity #7). Originally, the intent of this project activity was to provide ANC students with the opportunity to earn a B.S. degree on site through partnership with another baccalaureate degree-granting institution. However, as planning efforts for this activity progressed, ANC decided that its students would be better served by offering its own unique indigenous ecology B.S. degree, one grounded in the lifeways, community, traditions, and homelands of the Aaniinen and Nakoda nations of the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation. Following two years of a highly participatory and inclusive planning process, ANC launched the B.S. in Aaniiih Nakoda Ecology in 2020. Since that time, eight students have completed the program, and all graduates have found employment in a related field. As a result, the project exceeded its target outcome for students completing an on-site bachelor's degree by 33 percent. In addition, the Aaniiih Nakoda Ecology program is now a permanent and self-sustaining part of the college's curriculum, and it serves as the model and inspiration for the development and delivery of the college's second STEM bachelor's degree, a B.S. in Computer Information Systems. Not only has the project achieved and exceeded its anticipated outcomes for student participation, learning and achievement, but it has also transformed institutional STEM capacity at ANC.


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Scott R Friskics
